awd_titl_txt: US-Mexico Workshop on Interactive and Ubiquitous Computing uniting the Californias; Ensenada, Mexico, March 2011
awd_abstract_narration:
This US-Mexico award will support an international planning and research workshop on interactive and ubiquitous computing, involving approximately thirty-five scientists and students from the United States.  Organized by Dr. Gillian Hayes of the University of California-Irvine and Dr. Monica Tentori of the University of Baja California, together with Dr. Jesus Favela of CICESE, the Center for Scientific Research and Education of Ensenada, Mexico, the workshop is intended to promote an inter-cultural exchange and research cross-fertilization in the fields of human computer interactions (HCI) and ubiquitous computing (Ubicomp), the latter dealing with the creation of environments comprised of sensors, actuators, displays, and computational elements, embedded seamlessly in everyday objects, and connected through a continuous network.  In recent years, researchers have been focusing research efforts to solve significant human problems using tools and techniques from HCI and Ubicomp.  The intersection of both fields addresses a wide variety of topics from healthcare to sustainability to cross-cultural collaboration and requires truly multidisciplinary teams including people from academia, industry and community organizations.  

The workshop will feature in-depth discussions with a small group of senior-level researchers, including specialists from several areas of computer science, social science, and information science that make use of interactive and ubiquitous computing.  In addition, it will offer one-on-one mentoring and poster presentations.  Workshop outcomes will include recommendations for future directions of research, funding, policy, and education.

por.por_cntn:
In 2011, the US-Mexico Workshop on Interactive and Ubiquitous Computing uniting the Californias (WIUC2) was run as a one-track event accommodating 40 seven attendees: 12 researchers and 28 students. In terms of demographics, we were eager to recruit a diverse set of students and researchers—based on gender, race, topic, and institution. The institutional breakdown of our student participants was as follows: 10 were from UCI, 4 from UCSD, 9 from UABC, 12 from CICESE, and 5 from UCLA.

 

Funding

NSF generously funded the workshop at the level of $16883. This was the second effort held to promote inter-cultural exchange and cross-fertilization among the research HCI and Ubicomp communities near to the state of California. The workshop took place March 3-5, 2010 at the University of Baja California, at Ensenada, Baja California, Mexico. The co-chairs were selected one year before the workshop and were able to gain

valuable insights from the previous chairs and participants. We assembled a steering committee from across these many disciplines and from all over the state of California that evaluate the workshop schedule, and presented talks and posters.

• Paul Dourish, PhD University of California, Irvine

• Donald Patterson, PhD University of California, Irvine

• Gloria Mark, PhD University of California, Irvine

• Karen Cheng, PhD Charles Drew University

• Jim Hollan, PhD University of California, San Diego

• William G. Griswold, PhD University of California, San Diego

• Barry Brown, PhD University of California, San Diego

• Jesus Favela, PhD CICESE

• Victor M. Gonzalez, PhD CICESE

• Marcela D. Rodriguez, PhD University of Baja California (UABC)

• Alberto L. Moran, PhD University of Baja California (UABC

Outreach

In addition to posting the CFP on the workshop’s webpage, we posted announcements to a number of other lists in an attempt to increase participation from a diverse set of students. Our outreach included the following lists and individuals:

• CHI-Announcements

• UC Mexus

• Association for Computing Machinery

• IEEE Computer Society

• University of California

• Mexican association of Human-Computer Interaction

 

The primary activity of the workshop was to bring together a diverse set of researchers from across a range of disciplines, all which intersect with Interactive and Ubiquitous Computing. So, we provided several opportunities for attendees to engage in in-depth discussions creating an environment for exchange and conversation that will further enable progress on every project crafted at WIUC2. 

 

The preliminary results that came out from the workshop include:

1)    Three proposals submitted to UCMexu (n=2) and  Nokia (n=1). These proposals included collaborations between UCI-UABC, and CICESE-UCSD

2)    A student internship submitted to Xeros Parc between researchers from CICES and Parc.

3)    The incorporation of some researchers to the doctoral committee of students including researchers from UCI and UCSD

4)    The execution of a cross-cultural study between Mexico and USA including researchers from UABC and UCSD

 

 


Last Modified: 11/02/2011
Modified by: Gillian Hayes
